titleStmt.title: Letter from William F. Cody to Clarence W. Rowley, September 25, 1911
titleStmt.author: Cody, William Frederick, 1846-1917

distributor.name: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

notesStmt.note: Clarence W. Rowley, a Boston attorney, was hired to represent the Cody-Dyer Arizona Mining and Milling Company. Colonel Daniel Burns Dyer (1843-1912), former Indian agent, former president of the Augusta Railway in Georgia, and member of New York's Union League Club, became WFC's partner in the Cody-Dyer Mining and Milling Company in 1902. Campo Bonito, near Tucson, was a gold mine in which Cody and Dyer invested.

bibl.author: Cody, William Frederick, 1846-1917
bibl.title: Letter from William F. Cody to Clarence W. Rowley

supportDesc.support: Buffalo Bill's Wild West Combined With Pawnee Bill's Great Far East letterhead

opener.note: Buffalo Bill's Wild West Combined With Pawnee Bill's Great Far East

div1.p: Col Dyer was with Me when your good letter came. And he appreciated when you said we would cut out the Wyoming hunt if our mines. demanded our attention He has a monied friend in Boston he has invited to go out with us as soon as he hears from him he will get you two together

postscript.p: We cant get Deer Bear. & quails ne at Campo Bonito2
postscript.note: Col Dyer-uses a No 12 Winchester Pump shot gun3

back.note: Note 1: Cody did not include the year in his dateline. Buffalo Bill's Wild West Combined With Pawnee Bill's Great Far East performed in Carrollton, Missouri, on September 25, 1911.
Note 2: Campo Bonito was a mine located about 43 miles from Tucson in Pima County, Arizona.
Note 3: This sentence is written upside down, above the letterhead imprint.
